metadata.case_name: Bus Operators v. State of Andhra Pradesh
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 932 to 934 of 1968; Civil Appeals Nos. 1439 to 1441 of 1968; Writ Petitions Nos. 164 and 166 of 1968

facts.text: Appellants and writ petitioners carry on transport business in Andhra Pradesh under stage carriage permits granted under Motor Vehicles Act IV of 1939.

History of taxes levied on buses based on seating capacity, increasing over time; latest before 1963 was Validating Act of 1961 at Rs. 37.50 per seat per quarter from April 1, 1962, upheld in Nazeeria Motor Service v. A.P. State.
Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act V of 1963 came into force on March 20, 1963 after President's assent on February 2, 1963; consolidates and amends law for levy of tax on motor vehicles.
G.O.Ms. No. 601 Home Transport II Department dated March 27, 1963 imposed tax of Rs. 60 per seat per quarter on vehicles running less than 100 miles per day and Rs. 67.50 on higher mileage.
Writ petitions filed in 1963 challenging Act of 1963 and G.O. 601; High Court dismissed by common judgment dated September 6, 1963; first group of appeals (932-934/1968) from this.
High Court in 1963 found revenue from taxes (including motor spirit sales) not exceeding Rs. 6 crores while expenditure over Rs. 8.54 crores; tax compensatory, not violating Art. 301 or 304(b).

Notification No. 434 dated March 22, 1968 amended First Schedule increasing max tax to Rs. 121/135 per seat per quarter; G.O.Ms. No. 435 dated March 28, 1968 directed higher taxes based on mileage (Rs. 40 for 50 miles to Rs. 110 for over 200 miles).
Tax on spare buses at Rs. 30 per seat per quarter; operators with 5+ buses must keep 1 spare, 10+ keep 2.
Writ petitions challenging 1968 notifications dismissed by High Court on April 26, 1968; second group appeals (1439-1441/1968) and WP 164/166/1968 from this.
High Court 1968: Budget 1967-68 receipts Rs. 9,55,53,396 vs expenditure Rs. 9,81,65,411; 1968-69 receipts short by Rs. 50 lakhs; rejected Enquiry Committee report as misleading.
Road Transport Taxation Enquiry Committee report (Nov 1967) showed surplus in Andhra Pradesh 1964-67 (e.g., 1966-67 surplus Rs. 548.88 lakhs), but State affidavit called figures incorrect.
Increase in fares sanctioned simultaneously with tax hikes; competition for permits post-enhancement indicates profitability.
Buses ply inter-state; tax based on total mileage, but reciprocal arrangements with other states.

legal_issues.text: Whether the tax under Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act 1963 and notifications (G.O. 601/1963, G.O. 435/1968) is compensatory or a restriction on freedom of trade and commerce under Art. 301, reasonable under Art. 304(b) and Art. 19(1)(g)?
Whether levy on spare buses is justified?
Whether prior Presidential sanction under Art. 304(b) was validly obtained for 1968 levy?

petitioner_arguments.text: Taxes inconsistent with freedom of trade/commerce (Part XIII), infringe Art. 14; levied for general revenue, excess over road needs; Rs. 67.50 per seat unreasonable burden destroying business.
1968 increase ~50%, based on mileage including inter-state, unreasonable; not in public interest; spare buses tax illegal as not used.
No prior Presidential sanction for 1968 levy as required.

respondent_arguments.text: Tax compensatory; revenue < expenditure on roads (budget figures); increase offset by fare hikes; business profitable (permit competition); Enquiry Committee figures misleading.
Spare buses 'kept for use' under s.3(1), essential for service; reciprocal inter-state arrangements compensate.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Nazeeria; tax rates not substantially higher; budget shows revenue shortfall for roads; not unreasonable under Art. 19/301/304(b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revenue not exceeding Rs.6cr vs exp Rs.8.54cr (1963); similar in later budgets.

court_reasoning.text: Enquiry Committee report misleading per State affidavit; High Court scrutiny confirms compensatory nature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No surplus; tax meets expanding road needs.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence of business loss; fare increases and permit competition show profitability.
Spare buses taxable as 'kept for use'; essential for regulation.
Mileage-based tax valid with reciprocal arrangements.

holdings.text: Taxes under 1963 Act and notifications are compensatory, reasonable restrictions in public interest, not violating Arts. 19(1)(g), 301, 304(b).

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act V of 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers levy of tax by notification based on class, rates, mileage; amendment of schedules; upheld as constitutional

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Tests for reasonableness, public interest, compensatory tax; no violation found

outcome.summary: All appeals and writ petitions challenging the Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act 1963 and notifications G.O. 601/1963 and G.O. 435/1968 dismissed; taxes held valid compensatory levies not violating constitutional provisions.
